title: Some concepts (1)
text:
Nominations commence the gas flow in the pipeline. They encompass the request for the initiation of the transportation service. They specify the receipt and delivery locations for the request.
The receiving position is the point at which gas is transferred from the upstream pipeline to the carrying pipeline. The delivery site is the point when gas is transferred from the carrying pipeline to the downstream pipeline. Nominations encompass standard transportation, stipulations for supplementary fuel, and the notion of economic cycles.









Confirmations occur among linked pipes to guarantee that gas will be transported onto the pipeline and subsequently extracted in accordance with the shipperâ€™s nomination. The verifying parties utilize the information supplied in the nomination to reconcile the transactions that traverse the interconnect.
Scheduling involves the pipeline operator assessing the available gas flow against the required gas flow and organizing the requests in accordance with pipeline limitations. Segmentation and flow-day redirection are also addressed in Scheduling.


A Make-up is a mechanism in which shipper brings gas onto pipeline in case of â€œimbalance due-pipelineâ€ because shipper received more gas off of pipeline than it delivered onto pipeline.

title: Firm Service Contract in SISTRANGAS
text:
AÂ firm service contractÂ in natural gas transportation is a binding agreement between a pipeline operator and a user (also known as a â€œshipperâ€). When a contract isÂ firm, the operator is obligated to transport the shipper's gas up to aÂ Maximum Daily Quantity (MDQ), regardless of demand from other users. This guarantees that the shipper can move gas up to their contracted capacityâ€”even during system congestionâ€”ensuringÂ uninterrupted service.
Firm service contracts also grantÂ priority accessÂ in case of operational disruptions, giving these shippers an advantage over those withÂ interruptible service contracts. In essence, a firm contract securesÂ reserved pipeline capacityÂ with a high degree of reliability.

Open Access & Capacity Allocation in Mexico's SISTRANGAS
In Mexico, theÂ SISTRANGASÂ (Integrated Natural Gas Transportation and Storage System), operated byÂ CENAGAS, has allowed shippers to reserve capacity since its firstÂ open seasonÂ in 2017. During this process, each participating user was allocated anÂ MDQâ€”a contractual parameter measured in energy terms that, when managed effectively, ensuresÂ flexible and continuous supply.
After the initial capacity allocation, consumers had the option to:

Become direct SISTRANGAS usersÂ (entering a contract with CENAGAS).
Transfer their capacity to intermediariesÂ (gas marketers specializing in North America's complex supply logistics).

Recently,Â CENAGAS launched a contract renewal process, ensuring service continuity for existing users and consumers.Â Learn more here.


How Shippers & Consumers Benefit

ShippersÂ can use their reserved capacity toÂ secure supply for their own needsÂ or to serve their clients.
ConsumersÂ (whether or not they act as shippers) canÂ switch suppliers freelyÂ under Mexico'sÂ unbundled market structure, preventing them from being captive to a single pipeline owner.

Thanks toÂ open access, firm contracts, and post-2017 renewals, end-usersâ€”historically dependent onÂ PEMEX's monopolyâ€”now have direct or indirect access to pipeline routes.


Key Details on Contract Renewals

The renewal processÂ only extends or terminatesÂ existing contractsâ€”no changesÂ will be made to:

Reserved capacity (MDQ)
Primary injection/withdrawal points

However, the currentÂ capacity allocation structure warrants review.



Who Holds the Capacity? A Snapshot

PEMEX TransformaciÃ³n Industrial (PTRI)Â remains theÂ dominant shipper, despite market liberalization.
Some large consumers (e.g.,Â Braskem Idesa) manage their own transportation contracts.



Regionalization & Contract Distribution

SISTRANGAS can be divided intoÂ tariff zonesÂ (based on 2015 classifications).
Each shipper'sÂ injection/withdrawal nodesÂ indicate their market reach.

Contracted Capacities: Who Leads?

The largest firm capacity (6.8 Bcf/day total) is held underÂ contract SBF/002/16â€”belonging toÂ PEMEX TRI.
OnlyÂ 6.3 Bcf/dayÂ was allocated via open season, suggestingÂ CENAGAS has awarded additional firm capacity outside standard procedures.



Contract Expirations: What's Next?
Most active contractsÂ expire by mid-2023, with very few long-term agreements in place. This raises questions aboutÂ future capacity allocation strategies.


Final Insight
While Mexico's gas market has progressed since 2014,Â PEMEX still dominates. The renewal process will shape whether new players gain more influenceâ€”or if legacy shippers maintain control.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Natural gas is a vital energy source for millions of homes and businesses worldwide. As a relatively clean and efficient fuel, it powers electricity generation, heats homes, maintains essential services, and fuels industries.
In 2022, U.S. power generators produced aboutÂ 4,243 million megawatt-hours (MWh)Â of electricity, withÂ nearly 40%Â coming from natural gas. Similarly, in Mexico, gas-based technologies accounted for almost half of the country'sÂ 90,000 MWÂ of installed power capacity in 2021. Across North America and beyond, vast networks of natural gas pipelines ensure this crucial resource flows seamlessly from production fields to end users.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
section: The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks
text:
The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks
The natural gas pipeline system is an intricate web of steel pipesâ€”ranging from a few centimeters to several meters in diameterâ€”that transports gas from production sites to distribution hubs. These pipelines link supply sourcesâ€”such as gas wells, processing plants, international interconnections, and storage facilitiesâ€”to major consumption centers viaÂ city gates, where local distribution begins.

The U.S.Â boasts the world's most extensive pipeline network, spanning overÂ 340,000 kilometers.
CanadaÂ follows with nearlyÂ 61,000 kmÂ of pipelines.
MexicoÂ has a significant system exceedingÂ 17,000 km.

Together,Â North America holds about 40% of the world's gas transmission pipelines, ensuring reliable energy delivery across the continent.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
From Transmission to Consumption
Gas transmission lines typically deliver fuel toÂ city gates, where local distribution networks take over, supplying residential, commercial, and industrial customers. While these distribution systems directly serve end users, theÂ real market dynamicsâ€”pricing, capacity allocation, and supply balancingâ€”are driven by transmission pipelines.
KeyÂ hubs and interconnectionsÂ maintain system equilibrium, ensuring gas flows efficiently across regions and over time.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Why Pipelines Matter
Natural gas pipelines are the unsung heroes of modern life. In Mexico,Â electricity generation without natural gas would fall short of meeting demand. Beyond power, gas fuels:

Heating & cookingÂ in homes
Industrial productionÂ of glass, steel, cement, ceramics, and petrochemicals
Alternative fuelÂ for vehicles

TheÂ direct link between gas availability and economic prosperityÂ is undeniable. That's why investing inÂ skilled labor, technology, and transparent operationsÂ is crucial for ensuringÂ affordable, secure, and uninterrupted gas supply.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Ensuring Safe and Efficient Operations
A well-functioning pipeline system requires:

Constant monitoringÂ (leak detection, pressure checks, flow control)
Sophisticated technologyÂ to manage complex injection and withdrawal points
Effective commercial coordinationÂ to prevent imbalances, congestion, or underutilization

In North America, industry practices and regulations have shaped how market players interact. TheÂ North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB)Â plays a key role by defining protocols forÂ capacity management and gas scheduling. ItsÂ daily gas nomination cycleâ€”widely adopted in the U.S. and Canadaâ€”ensures seamless coordination across interconnected supply chains.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
section: The Need for Transparency and Accountability
text:
The Need for Transparency and Accountability
Pipelines are only as reliable as their operators.Â Lack of competition, restricted open access, or opaque contractsÂ can disrupt affordability and supply stabilityâ€”common challenges in transitioning gas markets like Mexico's.
To secure a stable energy future, the industry must prioritize:
âœ…Â Safety
âœ…Â Efficiency
âœ…Â Transparency
Natural gas will remain aÂ primary energy source for decades. Public awareness, data accessibility, and regulatory progress are essential to fostering aÂ modern, responsible gas industryÂ for future generations.

title: Understanding Gas Nominations and Commercial Cycles
text:
Natural gas scheduling in North America follows standardized commercial cycles defined by the North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB). These cycles structure how and when shippers submit nominations (requests to inject or withdraw gas) and how operators confirm and schedule these volumes. The main cycles are:
â€¢ Timely Cycle: The primary scheduling window (day-ahead).
â€¢ Evening Cycle: Allows for nomination revisions after the Timely cycle. in â€¢ Intraday Cycles 1â€“3: Provide opportunities to adjust flows closer to real time.
CENAGAS has adopted these NAESB protocols to manage nominations in the Sistema de Transporte y Almacenamiento Nacional Integrado de Gas Natural (SISTRANGAS). Each cycle helps update the national operating program (POGN), aiming to match expected supply with demand as conditions evolve throughout the day.

title: Understanding Gas Nominations and Commercial Cycles
section: The Case of Nodes V025 (Cactus) and V061 (Ramones)
text:
The Case of Nodes V025 (Cactus) and V061 (Ramones)
The chart below displays nominated energy flows (in TJ/day) at the injection point V025, broken down by commercial cycle, over the first half of 2025.









Node V025 is the commercial injection point associated with the Cactus Gas Processing Complex (Complejo Procesador de Gas Cactus), Mexicoâ€™s largest and most critical gas processing facility. Located in Tabasco and operated by Pemex, the CACTUS plant processes significant volumes of wet gas from southeastern production fields, removing liquids and impurities before delivering dry natural gas into the national pipeline network. As such, V025 functions as a key upstream interface between field production and the SISTRANGAS. Given its strategic role, nomination patterns at V025 reflect both production performance and system-wide supply availability, making it one of the most important nodes for monitoring operational balance.









Node V061 is the commercial injection point linked to Los Ramones Phase I, the starting segment of the Ramones pipeline system, Mexicoâ€™s most significant natural gas import and transport project. Located near Camargo, Tamaulipas, V061 receives large volumes of U.S. natural gas through the NET Mexico pipeline, which connects to the U.S. grid at the Eagle Ford shale region. As the primary northern injection hub into the SISTRANGAS, Node V061 plays a critical role in ensuring supply availability for central and southern Mexico. Its nomination activity reflects cross-border trade flows and serves as a key indicator of Mexicoâ€™s reliance on imported natural gas.
This information is central to how Mexicoâ€™s gas transmission systemâ€”managed by CENAGASâ€”ensures daily balance between supply and demand across its national pipeline network.

title: Understanding Gas Nominations and Commercial Cycles
text:
Operational Significance of Nominated Flows
The plotted data show the nominated injection quantities at node V025 for each cycle. These values are crucial for assessing operational imbalances, which occur when actual injections deviate from system needs. Importantly:
â€¢ Scheduled quantities represent flows that have been authorized by the operator (CENAGAS).
â€¢ These flows must correspond to nominated deliveries downstream, or to previously settled imbalance transactions (e.g., paybacks or over-deliveries).
If such a correspondence is missing, the injection creates a new operational imbalanceâ€”effectively gas entering the system without a planned destination or contractual justification.

Managing Imbalances
To manage these discrepancies, CENAGAS applies balancing mechanisms, which may include:
â€¢ Tolerance bands (permissible deviation margins),
â€¢ Make-up withdrawals (planned future compensations), and
â€¢ Imbalance charges (financial penalties or incentives to restore balance).
Persistent or large mismatches can jeopardize system reliability, affect pressure conditions, and trigger costly interventions.

title: Understanding Gas Nominations and Commercial Cycles
text:
Conclusion
Monitoring nominated flows across the NAESB commercial cyclesâ€”Timely, Evening, and Intraday 1â€“3â€”reveals important insights into how market participants respond to changing supply-demand dynamics throughout the gas day. In the plot, we observe that:
â€¢ Most activity concentrates around the Timely and Evening cycles, reflecting proactive day-ahead planning.
â€¢ Intraday nominations, while fewer, show the systemâ€™s flexibility to adapt to short-term fluctuations or unexpected events. These transactions are usually the prevailing operating signals.
These patterns are also behavioral indicators of how shippers manage uncertainty, respond to market signals, and engage with CENAGASâ€™s programming process.
Persistent discrepancies between nomination cycles or sudden shifts in intraday flows may signal emerging imbalances, strategy changes, or downstream issues. Thus, the temporal structure of nominationsâ€”not just their volumeâ€”is a key diagnostic tool. By analyzing when and how nominations are submitted, system operators and analysts can assess the quality of scheduling behavior, detect stress points in the network, and improve the accuracy of flow forecasts and balancing actions.
Understanding these scheduling patterns helps ensure that the gas system remains secure, predictable, and economically efficient, even in the face of operational variability.
